props.title: Das Futur II (German Future Perfect tense): usage, conjugation and exercises

sections.content: The Futur II (future perfect tense equivalent in English), is used in German to express actions that will have been completed at a certain point in the future. It is the equivalent of saying "will have done" in English. This tense highlights the completion of an action before a future moment
The Futur II is not commonly used on everyday languages, except for Literary Contexts and, in spoken language, polite assumptions.
We use the Futur II tense to express:

items.text: Completion in the Future: To indicate that an action will be completed before another future action or time:

example.audio: Bis morgen Abend werde ich die Arbeit erledigt haben
example.text: Example: Bis morgen Abend $__werde-werden[verb-link-hover]__$ ich die Arbeit $__erledigt-erledigen[verb-link-hover]__$ $__haben-haben[verb-link-hover]__$
example.translation: (By tomorrow evening, I will have finished the work)

items.text: Assumptions about the Past:To make assumptions or speculations about something that might have happened in the past

example.audio: Er wird wohl schon gegangen sein

items.text: Formal and Literary Contexts: While it is not as commonly used in everyday conversation, Futur II is more often seen in formal writing and literature:

sections.content: The Futur I tense is formed with the present tense of the auxiliary verb $__werden-werden[verb-link-hover]__$ and the infinitive of the main verb. Here's how to conjugate $__werden-werden[verb-link-hover]__$ in the present tense:

table.audio: ich werde, du wirst, (er) (sie) (es) wird, wir werden, ihr werdet, sie werden.

sections.content: Forming the Futur I tense will be very easy once you know the present tense of the verb $__werden-werden[verb-link-hover]__$, as the main verb takes the infinitive tense:

table.audio: ich werde spielen, du wirst spielen, (er) (sie) (es) wird spielen, wir werden spielen, ihr werdet spielen, sie werden spielen.

sections.content: In main clauses, the auxiliary verb is in the second position after the subject, and the past participle is at the end of the sentence.
